0.18.text:
Hi, I’m Hamish Black and welcome to Writing
On Games. A little heads up – today I’m

4.94.text:
going to be talking about Campo Santo’s
recent release Firewatch. This game is, as

9.50.text:
you may already know, almost entirely centred
on its narrative – as a result, it becomes

14.39.text:
incredibly difficult to discuss in a critical
sense without going into at least some cursory

19.18.text:
story elements. It’s a game that I’d recommend
playing, so if you haven’t played it yet

24.82.text:
and want to go in blind I’d suggest you
go and play it before watching this video.

28.29.text:
I’ll try to avoid any major spoilers but
what you define as a ‘major spoiler’ might

32.19.text:
be entirely different to me. With that in
mind, you have been warned. Now, let’s talk

36.16.text:
about Firewatch.
Firewatch is a game about choice. It is an

40.46.text:
aggressively linear game which focuses on
telling an incredibly singular tale that the

44.70.text:
player has little to no control over, but
it is about choice nonetheless. It is about

49.58.text:
choosing to run away from one’s problems,
it’s about choosing to start a new life,

54.29.text:
and the player gets a say in how their character
shapes their own identity, but ultimately

58.54.text:
every choice in the game proves to be futile.
The game always follows the same steps, hits

64.06.text:
the same narrative beats, and concludes in
the same way. How, then, does the game make

68.11.text:
these choices in any way meaningful? There
are indeed many choices in terms of dialogue

72.42.text:
between Henry and Delilah, but they never
actually amount to anything tangible in terms

76.71.text:
of how they affect the game’s progression
through its narrative. You get presented with

80.24.text:
a choice, you choose the line, Henry says
the line, Delilah responds and the game continues.

85.80.text:
Furthermore, critics of other adventure games
such as Life Is Strange and the developer’s

90.22.text:
previous work The Walking Dead Season One
have criticised the games for the illusory

94.77.text:
nature of their choices – that is to say,
they feel (rightly or wrongly) that the games

101.30.text:
pushed themselves as games where the player’s
choices could really affect the outcome of

105.04.text:
the story, and they were disappointed to find
out that their impact on the game’s outcome

109.05.text:
was perhaps not as grand as they might have
been lead to believe. Many players measure

113.26.text:
the rather nebulous concept of choice by how
different the presumed multiple endings of

118.32.text:
the game can turn out. However, as I will
attempt to exemplify through analysis of Firewatch

123.12.text:
and other games of a similar nature, this
is perhaps not the best metric by which to

125.16.text:
measure the value of a game’s choices. In
fact, one might go so far as to say that the

129.42.text:
seemingly inconsequential nature of the choices
presented to the player in games like Firewatch

134.56.text:
and Kentucky Route Zero for example actually
end up giving the player a greater sense of

136.88.text:
place within the world their character inhabits.
Perhaps we can analyse Firewatch’s approach

142.58.text:
to character in the way that Barthes imagines
the death of the author – in his essay on

147.42.text:
the concept, whilst analysing and asking hypothetical
questions of the identity of the author in

153.86.text:
Balzac’s Sarrasine, he states that:
It will always be impossible to know, for

156.84.text:
the good reason that all writing is itself
this special voice, consisting of several

161.42.text:
indiscernible voices, and that literature
is precisely the invention of this voice,

166.24.text:
to which we cannot assign a specific origin:
literature is… the trap where all identity

171.49.text:
is lost, beginning with the very identity
of the body that writes. Probably this has

176.89.text:
always been the case: once an action is recounted…
this disjunction occurs, the voice loses its

182.45.text:
origin, the author enters his own death, writing
begins.

186.09.text:
It’s important to note that Barthes here
is largely discussing the idea of metafiction,

190.84.text:
or texts that are about the idea of being
a text, which Firewatch very much is not,

199.79.text:
but there are some interesting parallels to
be drawn here. This idea of ‘writing beginning’

205.71.text:
once the origin of the author becomes obfuscated
and therefore becomes placed on the person

210.37.text:
experiencing a text, is perhaps at the very
heart of the way games like Firewatch present

217.45.text:
their choices to the player. The simple dialogue
choices presented to the player might not

222.62.text:
alter the overarching story in any particularly
meaningful way, but in the moments they are

227.36.text:
presented to the player, they help the player
subtly shape their character (or at the very

232.09.text:
least their understanding of the character)
which in turn helps contextualise the more

236.26.text:
significant narrative beats at a more identifiably
individual level. For example, take one of

241.87.text:
the earliest scenarios in the game – where
Henry confronts some drunken teenagers setting

245.98.text:
off fireworks at the lake. The outcome of
this situation will always end with Henry

249.41.text:
taking some form of action (or inaction) and
the teenagers becoming annoyed and running

254.12.text:
off. The game builds up to this situation
by first presenting the player with the remnants

258.34.text:
of the teenager’s excess – beer cans strewn
everywhere allow Henry the option to pick

262.99.text:
these up or leave them be, as well as presenting
the option of taking some whiskey for himself.

268.54.text:
He then passes by the teenager’s clothes
which Delilah ribs him about, until finally

272.93.text:
he is presented with the teenagers themselves,
naked, accusing Henry of being a pervert,

277.72.text:
with the stereo blasting. One can do many
things here, but the outcome is always the

282.36.text:
same – Henry walks away having caused some
form of annoyance to the teenagers, causing

286.87.text:
them to swim away.
What’s intriguing about this is that despite

290.01.text:
the outcome always being the same, the way
the player navigates the dialogue choices

294.49.text:
presented to them from as early as the very
beginning of the game shape Henry’s character

299.32.text:
in very subtle ways which contextualise this
situation somewhat differently. With the text

305.19.text:
segment at the start describing the decline
of his wife’s health, players can make decisions

309.61.text:
regarding Henry’s reactions to various situations.
Is the player’s Henry the kind of guy that

314.47.text:
will get visibly mad when she comes in late
or will he pretend that everything is OK and

319.34.text:
let the anger fester due to his inability
to assert himself? Is he the kind of person

323.98.text:
who worries enough to lock his ill wife in
her room whilst he goes to drink, or does

328.69.text:
he treat the situation with a reckless abandon
due to his distance to the situation around

334.42.text:
him? These small choices help to characterise
Henry in drastically different ways – regardless

339.03.text:
of your choices he is going to be flawed and
his life will play out the same, but in the

343.58.text:
player’s head it calibrates Henry’s character
as either an assertive, violent asshole, or

348.87.text:
an awkward, clumsy oaf. This continues as
the player comes across the beer cans – is

353.56.text:
the player’s Henry the kind of person to
obsessively pick up every can despite its

358.22.text:
lack of impact on the larger narrative? Does
he take the whiskey for himself or confiscate

362.68.text:
it? When he comes across the clothes, does
he respond to Delilah’s quips or does he

366.73.text:
become coy about it? All these choices create
something of a metagame, where each choice

371.57.text:
branches out into the same set of choices
but with a different context depending on

376.41.text:
your previous choices – all for the sake
of contextualising Henry’s character in

380.46.text:
the player’s head. For example, does Henry
leave the cans and go straight for the whiskey

384.31.text:
because he’s a borderline alcoholic that
doesn’t care about his job, or does he treat

388.98.text:
the whiskey as a reward for doing his job
(still hinting at some kind of alcohol problem),

393.62.text:
or does he confiscate everything altogether?
These choices culminate in the meeting with

397.43.text:
the teenagers, which now can take on several
different forms of context in the player’s

401.89.text:
head. Does Henry shyly and awkwardly ask the
teens to stop setting off fireworks before

406.48.text:
just walking away from their barrage of emasculating
insults? Does he take the stereo and run (still

412.06.text:
running away from confrontation in a situation
where his opponents cannot effectively respond)?

416.56.text:
Or, does he present his aggressive side by
picking up the stereo and violently tossing

420.86.text:
it into the water before shouting at the teenagers?
Again, it all ends in the same way – the

426.25.text:
teenagers swim away. However, each subtle
choice the player has made up until this point

431.55.text:
that seemingly have no consequence on the
game at large help them make this cumulative

436.28.text:
decision of how they are to deal with the
situation regarding the teens. These subtle

440.65.text:
dialogue choices place the authorship of the
more subtle elements of Henry’s character

445.17.text:
onto the player, and therefore each situation
becomes more meaningful to the player as it

449.86.text:
is their individual, subtly crafted version
of Henry experiencing and responding to them.

456.15.text:
Each version the player can create in their
heads will inevitably be flawed as the larger

460.88.text:
narrative beats remain the same for everyone,
but the ways in which he is flawed are left

465.13.text:
up to the player. Is he a violent thug, an
apathetic weirdo or an awkward manchild? These

470.84.text:
outcomes are all Henry, as written and constructed
by the developers and writers, but the decision

476.38.text:
as to which version of Henry the player takes
on is left at almost every turn to the player.

481.65.text:
This, arguably, is the kind of situation Barthes
talks about when he states that ‘the unity

486.33.text:
of a text is not its origin, but its destination’.
In order to make the game’s choices more

491.27.text:
meaningful to the player, the writers must
give up authority in a way that only games

495.57.text:
can allow, and place faith in the intelligence
of the player to value consistency in their

500.31.text:
vision of the character.
Is the game fully successful in achieving

504.15.text:
this lofty vision? Not entirely. I would argue
that the game almost doesn’t go far enough

508.90.text:
with the idea of transferring authorship onto
the player. The main reason for this, as I

513.03.text:
see it, is that the game doesn’t seem to
know whether it wants to be this compelling

516.72.text:
character drama based on the player’s vision
of Henry formed through subtle dialogue choices,

521.76.text:
or if it wants to focus on the creeping mystery,
until right at the game’s conclusion, and

526.20.text:
ends up resolving neither in a particularly
satisfying way as a result (and another warning,

530.95.text:
this section might get into some spoilers
but I’ll avoid them as best as I can). In

535.09.text:
order to illustrate this I’m going to have
to compare it to what may be seen as a somewhat

538.82.text:
easy comparison, but it’s apt – Gone Home.
These games, on the surface, appear to do

543.73.text:
very similar things – they both feature
some form of mystery regarding the character’s

548.15.text:
place in the world, and ultimately resolve
to reveal that the mystery is more grounded

552.43.text:
and human than the player might have initially
imagined. However, the way in which both games

556.71.text:
go about this is what differentiates them.
Gone Home almost starts with a kind of unbearable

561.24.text:
tension (in many ways it almost feels like
a horror game) but as the game progresses

565.15.text:
this tension that there might be strange,
occult and hostile events taking place slowly

569.82.text:
gives way to a more human story about a relative’s
struggles to find their sexual identity. The

574.32.text:
tension starts high, but gradually falls away,
allowing the player to slowly become accustomed

579.47.text:
to the shift in focus.
Firewatch does the opposite, and ends up bungling

583.80.text:
its mystery as a result. It starts off with
almost no mystery whatsoever, and then as

590.19.text:
the game goes on begins to hint more and more
to the player that something strange might

594.43.text:
be happening. It actually builds this tension
in a pretty masterful way – constantly upping

599.56.text:
the ante to the point where the player begins
to question the reality they find themselves

603.44.text:
in and foregrounding some of the more mechanical
elements of the game (the recordings of radio

608.25.text:
conversations, for example, presented almost
like a script), and every turn the player

611.97.text:
takes as a result feels like it could result
in grave danger. This tension is taken to

615.26.text:
almost absurd levels as the player begins
to wonder about potential government conspiracies,

620.68.text:
or even if the developers are playing some
kind of sinister mindgames with the player…

625.25.text:
only for the game to do the Gone Home thing
and reveal to the player that actually the

628.94.text:
mystery doesn’t matter and the whole point
of the story was the building up of Henry

632.81.text:
and Delilah’s relationship. Not only was
this a disappointingly obvious way for the

636.78.text:
story to go, the difference between Gone Home
and Firewatch is the way that Gone Home allows

641.66.text:
the player to acclimatise early on to the
idea that the mystery doesn’t matter, whereas

648.06.text:
Firewatch builds the mystery and tension to
a point where it seems like the developers

652.30.text:
want the player to focus on that rather than
the relationship between Henry and Delilah.

656.87.text:
It represents a disappointing lack of consistency
in a game which could have truly been considered

661.36.text:
one of the better implementations of narrative
delivery in a game if the writers had just

665.67.text:
stuck with either the relationship between
Henry and Delilah and the way the player’s

669.77.text:
choices contextualise larger situations, or
stick the landing in terms of the mystery

674.61.text:
by providing it a satisfactory conclusion,
worthy of the tension the game creates before

678.80.text:
then.
Despite this lack of a satisfactory conclusion

681.83.text:
however, it is hard to deny that at least
initially the game does some incredibly interesting

686.32.text:
things with the notion of player choice. If
we imagine that The Walking Dead Season One

690.52.text:
presents the player with numerous massive
decisions that shape the nature of the larger

694.85.text:
narrative going forward but change little
about the way the player views the characters,

699.55.text:
Firewatch chooses to focus on how the player
contextualises very singular events by bringing

704.67.text:
the consequences of their choices down to
a micro, character-driven level. This is where

709.00.text:
Firewatch absolutely shines in my opinion,
and as a result I would still recommend people

713.16.text:
pick up and play. If it exemplifies anything
however, it’s that games as a medium are

717.59.text:
still in a state of constant flux – we are
far from reaching the supposed pinnacle of

722.03.text:
narrative delivery in games at this point,
and these games can very much be viewed as

725.93.text:
narrative experiments, which in turn draw
from the narrative experiments in games of

730.25.text:
the past few years such as The Stanley Parable
or Dear Esther (which, for the record, is

735.72.text:
one of the least fulfilling experiences I
have ever had playing a game, but it was significant

740.56.text:
for the development of the medium nonetheless).
It is incredibly interesting to trace the

744.35.text:
lineage of this game through those earlier
experiments in narrative delivery in games

748.51.text:
that seemed so revolutionary at the time but
now feel strangely dated. It’s also immensely

753.89.text:
exciting, however, to imagine how these kinds
of games can develop and iterate on both the

758.00.text:
successes and shortcomings of these games,
and I for one very much look forward to engaging

764.10.text:
with the evolving discourse as more of these
games are released. Also, I should say that

767.36.text:
I’m very happy to have you along for the
ride with me on this as well. And with that

768.90.text:
said, I’m Hamish Black and that concludes
yet another episode of Writing On Games. Thanks

772.47.text:
very much for watching and I’ll see you
next time.
